about: Infrastructure reliability, DevOps, CI/CD, cloud platforms.
aboutl:
I help improve infrastructure reliability, automate deployments, and streamline interactions between product and infrastructure teams.

My background as a system administrator has given me a comprehensive view of technical environments: networking, security, storage, data, and automation.

Today, I build on this foundation to contribute, document, share knowledge, and explore what’s next, from open source to decentralized cloud and AI.

I move forward as a curious craftsman, with a taste for practical solutions and ideas to share.

projets.stack: Raspberry Pi Zero, Syncthing, Linux USB gadget
projets.probleme: It’s sometimes complicated to keep data synchronized across different PCs, locations, and platforms: desktop, laptop, work PC, changing locations...
solution: An active synchronization key that backs up and versions your important files in the background.
Detected as a standard USB data key and also as a software key.
It can connect to Wi-Fi networks and synchronize with other keys; simply put two keys in sync mode using a physical button.
The prototype is a Raspberry Pi Zero with Debian and gadget mode, allowing detection as a USB data key.
It has multiple partitions: one for data, one for a restore point, and one for the OS.
The data synchronization system is Syncthing.
apprentissage: UX limitations without an interface
For unknown reasons, behavior varied completely from one PC to another, even on Windows.
On my dev PC, everything worked, but on others, it was random.
The idea seemed simple, but every day brought a new challenge.
I had buyers for the product; someone even paid me, and I couldn’t refuse, while others were ready to do so.
I also found people willing to help with development. A friend even joined me for some brainstorming.

projets.stack: ESP8266, Wi-Fi, breadboard, 3D print, Arduino, Heroku, MQTT, GitLab CI
projets.probleme:
Introduce IoT with a simple, autonomous connected object.
I designed a fun learning prototype, but the organizer expected a finished product :-D
It was a workshop where I gave participants the parts, and they had to do the wiring, assembly, and configuration themselves. They enjoyed it. From my perspective, it was a success. From the organizer’s perspective, I was selling an unfinished product too expensively (in the sense of lacking polish).
solution: Functional battery-powered prototype without soldering
3D-printed casing, ESP8266 on a mini breadboard
Used in a workshop with 12 Orange Business directors
Complete magnet with a screen, connectable to Wi-Fi + battery + casing + web interface for interaction
Automatic deployment of the entire environment on Heroku (complexity hidden)
apprentissage: Gap between technical prototype and expectations for a finished product
Key role of mediation in an innovation context
3D design with OpenSCAD
Took much longer than expected to complete, but we managed to achieve something functional
